conclusion: The working principle of the electromagnetic railgun is that the projectile to be launched can move freely between two parallel rails and maintain good contact with the rails. Current flows in from one rail, passes through the conductive projectile, and then flows back through the other rail. The rail current generates a magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the rails at the projectile (which can be considered as a uniform magnetic field). The electrified projectile is then propelled at high speed along the rails due to the Lorentz force acting on it.

Xiao Ming purchased a railgun model online, with a rail length of ( L = 0.5 m ), a parallel rail spacing of ( d = 0.02 m ), a projectile mass of ( m = 0.02 kg ), a rail current of ( I = 10 A ), and a magnetic field strength of ( B = 1 T ). All resistances are neglected.

The image illustrates the working principle of an electromagnetic railgun. It shows a projectile moving between two parallel rails, with current flowing from one rail, through the projectile, and back to the other rail. The rail current generates a magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the rails at the projectile, causing it to be propelled at high speed.

premise: The Lorentz force F acting on the projectile is given by F = I * B * d.
conclusion: Substitute the given values: I = 10 A, B = 1 T, d = 0.02 m, F = 10 * 1 * 0.02 = 0.2 N.

premise: The force F causes the projectile to accelerate from rest. Use the equation of motion: F = (m * v^2) / L.
conclusion: Substitute the given values: m = 0.02 kg, L = 0.5 m, 0.2 = (0.02 * v^2) / 0.5, v^2 = (0.2 * 0.5) / 0.02 = 5, v = sqrt(5) m/s.

premise: The power P of the electromagnetic railgun is given by P = F * v.
conclusion: Calculate the final power value: P = 0.2 * sqrt(5) W.
